```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
```

The [`{d6geodata}` package](https://github.com/EcoDynIZW/d6geodata) aims to access the data from the Geodata archive of the Ecological Dynamics Department (for members only!)

The two main functions are:

- `geo_overview()` 
- `get_geodata()`


```{r install, eval=2}
devtools::install_github("EcoDynIZW/d6geodata")
library(d6geodata)
```

If you want to get geodata we already have in our Geodata archive you have two options: navigate to the EcoDynIZW Website, click on wikis and select [Geodata](https://ecodynizw.github.io/geodata.html). There you willll find several raster layers and vector data including maps and metadata. In the metadata section, you will find the `folder_name`. You can copy this and use this together with `get_geodata()` function to get the data from our PopDynCloud. Another option is the function called `get_overview()`. There you can select which data and from which location you want to have a list of data we have. 

```{r example geo_overview, eval=FALSE}
#d6geodata::geo_overview("C:/PopDynCloud")
```

![](man/get_overview_example_1.PNG)
![](man/get_overview_example_2.PNG)

Now you can copy the name of one of the layers and paste it into the `get_geodata()` function:

```{r example get_geodata}
corine <-
  d6geodata::get_geodata(
    data_name = "corine_berlin_2015_20m_03035_tif",
    path_to_cloud = "E:/PopDynCloud",
    download_data = FALSE
  )
```

If you set `download_data = TRUE` the data will be download and copied to your `data-raw` folder. If the `data-raw` folder does not exist, it will create one.

# Additional functions

The three functions `plot_binary_map()`, `plot_qualitative_map()`, and plot `plot_quantitative_map()` can be used to add the respective color schemes we used for the Geodata wiki page, but for raster data only!

```{r plotting functions, eval=FALSE}
p_base_map + plot_binary_map(tif = tif)
p_base_map + plot_qualitative_map(tif = tif)
p_base_map + plot_quantitative_map(tif = tif)
```
